turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Any word from Canada?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: Spies from Quebec confirm that the British are sending an entire fleet down Lake Champlain...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: A fleet?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: My God... They mean to finish us. What about Arnold?  He's up there.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: What can he do?  The British have massive superiority.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: If we have any hope for a compromise or truce with England now, we have to hold on here:  our men must believe they can win -- the British must believe that somehow, in some mad, impossible way we might actually be able to hurt them.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: I understand, George.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Colonel Reed...

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: George!  So good to be back!

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: That damned Arnold is here, isn't he?  Did you know he lost all his ships?  Outrageous and completely unacceptable.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Joseph, the British spent thousands of pounds and precious months putting together a fleet that Arnold stopped by sacrificing a heap of old barges.  In my opinion he saved my army.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: Well, George, Congress just passed a resolution censuring Arnold for destruction of government property. I wouldn't cast my fate with that man.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: A grand scheme?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: A ground swell-Christian movement, George, you see?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: No.  As a matter of fact I haven't the slightest idea what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: To assert the rights of our founding fathers!  This country was colonized by Christians!  This shall become a Christian revolution.  Surely as a good Christian you understand that!

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: What do you mean you're not a Christian?  Of course you're a Christian, we're all Christians...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I mean, I'm a Deist.  A belief I share with the likes of Tom Jefferson and Ben Franklin.  Surely you knew that.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: No, I did not.  Really?  Well, what the hell is a deist, precisely?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: But the Hessians are there!  No one can beat them!  That's why Cornwallis stationed them there! They have the post of honor!  They are invincible!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: They are also very religious.  So, we will attack them three days from now, on Christmas.  One force under me, and another to the south under Colonel Cadwalader...

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: George, I'm afraid if you go through with this madness I must tender my resignation as your aide. I see where we're headed, you're putting your trust in the likes of Hamilton and Arnold...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: How many generals do we have like Arnold?  He's got guts -- he's vain, and he fights!

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: And, Hamilton?  Greene?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: They help me understand why we fight.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: Understand?  You need to be listening to people like John Adams, and to keep the best interest of the country first in your mind!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Joseph, are you afraid to cross that river with me?  I accept your resignation.  With regret.  You have leave to return to Philadelphia...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Gentlemen, let me get to the point, I can't see the wisdom of pursuing this old court-martial against General Arnold.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: The man is a traitor!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: How can you say that?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Arnold is indispensable, do you understand?  I need Arnold to help me win this war!

turns.speaker: JOSEPH REED
turns.text: Well, I shall deny him to you!  He is evil on earth!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Are you all going insane!? Benedict Arnold!  The man who stopped the British on Lake Champlain!  Who carried the day at Saratoga!  Goddamn-it, Joseph, you own two mansions, ride in an expensive, Tory coach!  You are all nothing but a pack of greedy pigs!

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: However, through my relations with members of his majesty's court, I am a representative of the French government whose deepest desire is to be one people, united with our American brothers in arms to defeat the rapacious armies of King George of England.  Vive la France!  Vive l'Amerique!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: We have more officers created by Congress than we know what to do with.

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: But, general, I assure you my motives are sincere.

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: Sir, please accept my commission from Congress... and...  You must see this portrait of my beautiful wife, Adrienne, we had the most perfect little baby girl just before I left.  Her name is Henriette...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: What I want to know is sir:  where is your daddy?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Gentlemen, my I introduce a French gentleman, recently appointed major general by Congress...  Marie Joseph Paul Yves Roch Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette. General Lafayette has brought us the greetings and goodwill of his countrymen, and... how many cases of muskets, Mon petite Marquis?

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: Uh... none just now, but...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: 'Continentals', Congress' paper money.  It was worthless to start with, but as you see, counter feiters have made them even less than worthless.  Can you tell which one is fake?

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: I... they look both the same.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: The one with 'Philadelphia' spelled correctly is the counterfeit.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: No, please; an advance on your salary.

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: Mon General, I have come here to learn and to give, not to take.  I am serving without salary.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: You must be very rich.

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: I am.  Then, I understand you too serve without salary.  You know, since your charming little victories at Trenton and Princeton, the French court is softening.  I expect any time now a ship load of supplies...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: 'Charming little victories?' Please don't expect much more of us, Monsieur.

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: I only meant...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: These supplies...?

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: Muskets and uniforms and Bayonets.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: And how rusty are these muskets?

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: Sir, these are our finest firearms from the armory at Charleville! They are a gift from the people of France!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Well, we will accept these charming little gifts.  When we see them. Meanwhile, please, take your pick of a horse.

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: I rode here, on my horse.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Chose another.  Any general worth anything should have a brace of horses.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Because, if the British got off their asses and came up here, now, we would be smashed.  And the revolution would be finished.  Tell King Louis, it's that bad.

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: Yes, I will write him and tell his ministers and the court.

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: Like flowers after the snow melts.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: When the snow melts, mon petite Marquis, I suspect the only thing blossoming will be bright red British soldiers.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: What is it, Marquis?

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: My baby daughter has died... my baby... mon petite Henriette...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: My God!  Who ordered this retreat?!

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: General Lee, sir!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Get these men back in line!

turns.speaker: LAFAYETTE
turns.text: I feel the same, sir.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I will continue with our French allies, concentrating on New York.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: It's another demonstration against the king.  This is the wildest yet.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: My God, these people mean to go to war!  They really mean it.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Surely you knew this was coming.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: War?  No!  I did not!  When you said compromise was possible I believed it was probable.  There's no middle ground at all?  We're the King's children!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Our beloved father, the King, also refuses to bend.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: But to go to war over trade, over money?  Surely there's still time for a compromise.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Of course, if it were that simple.  These people?  They're after something else...

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: My God, what?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: The eternal dream of the disenfranchised, my dear:  a classless world.  Not a very real expectation.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Well, a very real expectation is the British will hang you!  They'll burn Mount Vernon and they'll hang you!  Our marriage is a business just as surely as...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I'm very aware of that.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I can not allow the fortune in slaves my first husband created and what our partnership has elevated, to be destroyed...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Don't be ridiculous, of course that won't happen.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Have you been reading what Minister Jefferson has to say?  If he had his way, all our slaves would be freed no matter what the outcome. And that would destroy us as surely as a British victory.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: The day Tom Jefferson frees a slave I'll ride naked through the streets of Williamsburg on a mule.  Tom Jefferson is one of those people who talks big and acts small.  The only man out there who really does what he says is Sam Adams and everyone thinks he's crazy.  Believe me, this 'disturbance' isn't going to last long.  You have to understand, congress is a chicken coop full of foxes, Martha, each and every one has his eye on a nice, fat prize.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: And, what 'prize' do you see?  What could we possible gain?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Everything.  If we force Britain into concessions it will open up the western lands -- and that would be a boon for our family.  We already have more slaves than we need, but we need more land.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: But, as usual, it will not go well for... them.  Martha, you must trust me.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: You're no fool, George.  You never have been.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: "Liberty, Virtue, Country"... That's from Cato... you know, that play about the noble Romans?  As I was riding up to Philadelphia, I found myself thinking about the old days...

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: When you lived with the Fairfaxes?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: When I was a young man we used to recite Cato... We would come together recite it like they were words from heaven.  Devotion to country, duty, purity of heart... Purity of heart.  I was drunk on something then...

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: That's when Sally Fairfax was tutoring you...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: That's right...

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: And have you heard anything from our dear friend, Sally?  What with all the rumors getting back to England.  I thought she might inquire after us.  But then I believe she always looked down on us.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Did you know that Jefferson has proposed a law in Virginia aiming at an absolute separation of state from the church?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I think I heard that.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: It's an anti-Christian dogma!  I cannot believe you are so calm about it!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: What else?  From Virginia?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Well, I wouldn't want to trouble you with this now.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Martha... what?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Virginia is outraged with your order allowing Negroes to fight in the army.  There's a deep feeling of hurt and betrayal.  They wanted you commander because they expected you would look out for our interests.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: To win this war I need an army.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Oh, indeed?  You know very well people are frightened of arming the Negroes!  They beg you to consider the future.  What good is a revolution if it overturns those things we cherish!?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: What's the point of a revolution if it doesn't?

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Some things must never change.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Is that why you come in here tossing pennies to my starving men? It's damned condescending!

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Don't condescend to me!  We have both of us prospered from the arrangements of our kind...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Our 'kind'?  What is that supposed to mean?  These men are all I have left and they stay because they will fight!  They desire it!  They seek it!  Of course Virginia is terrified!  For my soldiers this is a war to obliterate the 'upper class' from the face of the earth! Should I tell them all to go home because if they win it will ruin me!?  It is impossible for me to imagine that Negroes are fighting so that only white men may be free! If we win this war they will own this country too!

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Well, we must keep in mind the Dower Laws.  One third of everything we have is mine and since our Negroes have been interbreeding, it would be legally impossible to distinguish them.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Martha!  For God's sake!

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Leave me, now sir, I am tired.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Come out and meet my soldiers. They're good people.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: Not today.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I want you to see our hospital.

turns.speaker: MARTHA
turns.text: I don't want to see your hospital.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: We can't take them.  Are you all right?

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: We're leaving them?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: They're finished, they can't help us anymore!  They've done their duty, General Greene, now you do yours!

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: Yessir!

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: Colonel Washington?  Colonel Nathanael Greene, Rhode Island Militia.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Yes, yes, happy to meet you.

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: I... I'm possessed of the idea of a command in your army, sir.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: It isn't my army yet, Colonel Greene.  Looks like you've seen some action -- did you hurt your leg, in a fight?

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: I was born with a limp, sir.  The Militia used to hate it when I marches with them because my pike would always sway...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: But, you do come from a military family?

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: I have commanded the Rhode Island Militia for a year now.  My father is an ironmaster.  As was I.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: A horseshoer?

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: Yes, but I've spent the last winter studying all the great battles of history.  And I read the lives of Caesar, Alexander, Hannibal...  Sir, I'm volunteering you the wholehearted support of the Rhode Island army.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: The only way to get discipline into these men is to beat it into them! Fifty lashes each!

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: Sir, Congress hasn't issued their pay for two months, many have not eaten properly for at least that long.  You're being a little hard on them, don't you think?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Nathanael, someone bred to station, bred to being a gentleman -- unlike these men -- his sense of duty naturally prevails over the baser needs.

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: Well sir, I was an ironmaster before you got me.  Maybe I will let you down yet.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I certainly didn't mean you.  Of course you are a gentleman, an officer and a gentleman.

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: You wrong me, general; I am an officer and a horse-shoer.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: General Greene?

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: I'm with Captain Hamilton.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Yes, I thought that's how you'd feel, Nathanael.

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: They're just disgusting, jealous, bottom-feeding swine.  It's their nature.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: You have a free tongue, Captain Hamilton.

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: Sir, if you don't mind my saying, I don't understand your history at all.  I mean, why would you want to win the war?  You're not after glory, like Benedict...  You're a slave owner, and yet you invite blacks to fight in your army.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: You don't believe I can fight from a sense of duty and patriotism?

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: No.  We're all of us after something.  It's easy for me to fight for the common man.  My father could only dream that I would be... a general someday?  And what of my daughter or son?  I know what I'm after.  But now, with all this talk about compromise?  It means the rich will just be more wealthy and the common man has no hope.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I will not betray you, Nathanael.

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: But you are an aristocrat and a slave owner.  Sir.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: At one time I could have chosen not to be.

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: Then, maybe I do see what you're after -- perhaps... you get to chose again...

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: What the hell are we doing?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: You've got to stop them here or our whole line will cave-in!  It's all right boys, I'm here!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Nathanael, I'm sending you to Virginia to head the southern army, to harass Cornwallis.  Marquis, you must go with him.

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: I'm honored, but, reluctant to leave you.

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: Sir, I have to act on instructions from you ordering thirty copies of your own dress uniform...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: They're for my bodyguard.  I have an absolute conviction that Arnold is planning to have me assassinated!  It will be harder if I am surrounded by a body of men who look like me, don't you think?

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: Yes sir, it's a wise idea...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Well, this must be about something!

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: It is; we need you George.

turns.speaker: NATHANAEL GREENE
turns.text: If the constitution is ratified... we'll have a country.  They'll want to elect you president of the convention, which means president of the country.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: You know, I came back to Mount Vernon to retire.  I don't need to be in government.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Well, the widow Curtis will bring you riches, position, land, even half-grown children.  You won't have to do anything at all!  You shan't have to do another thing to prove yourself.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: You know very well who it is that I love.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Is that the truth?  Well, we can't carry on like animals any longer.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: George, you know I only love you, but...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: But not more than your comfort.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: And what is this, then?  Been off to fight the French because you are a patriot?  Or is this you, gaining your long sought after rise in society by becoming victorious in war!?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: That's a lie!

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Is it?  William says now you have requested a British Commission, why not colonial?  I'll clear it up for you, sir, because as a British officer you can lord over colonial yokels -- more than that, it will even get you into polite society! Your dream come true, George, the only dream that really matters to you.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Perhaps you've been counting my acres, Mrs. Fairfax, and discovered exactly how poor I really am.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Now that is a lie!  See how much you want to create a scandal in exchange for a glowing reputation and polite society laid at your feet!  When you break off your engagement to Martha Curtis, I'll divorce William!  Do you hear?  You get what you want from this world, then throw it all away on love!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I'd throw everything away for you.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: You remember, George, when we were 'studying' the great philosophers?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I remember a pair of young philosophers once, who laughed at the world.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Well, I remember a philosopher who said something that I used to think was just another of those stupid class denouncements... but which I now see means us all.

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Really?  Which precious homily was it?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: "Mankind is born free, but everywhere he is in chains..."

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: So, you are William's wild young neighbor?  Or should I say, 'brother'; William claims you as a member of his family.  I have heard so many unflattering tales about you, and I understand, that except for you, this 'family' is quite cultivated.

turns.speaker: WILLIAM
turns.text: George, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Oh, but you must not mind my talking about you!  In fact, William says my main job here at Belvoir is to civilize you; to make an honest English gentleman out of you.

turns.speaker: WILLIAM
turns.text: That's not what I said!  Now, Sally, you're embarrassing me!  Watch out for her, George; she talks refinement, but she has a barbarous soul!

turns.speaker: WILLIAM
turns.text: We can grow three primary crops in a season and, if we have some luck, we get a forth.  The temperature is generally mild.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Except for that, quite like home; England, that is.

turns.speaker: WILLIAM
turns.text: Hear that, George?  Sally's actually taken to thinking of this clod of earth as her home.  And it's her first tour.  We're gratified, aren't we George?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Think what the play means, William. Perhaps these words have a place in the real world.

turns.speaker: WILLIAM
turns.text: Words, words, words!  Sally has been tutoring George in the philosophies, isn't that right?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Where... do those men come from, George?

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: Africa, of course.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Africa?  That's so far?  How do they get here?

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: Slavers capture them and bring them here.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Capture them?  Well, I've never seen anything like it, so... of course I'm curious.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: Sally, our slave system is a British law...

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: The word 'minuet' finds its source in minitus, which is Latin meaning 'small' or 'orderly'.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: Or, 'civilized'.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: In the minuet, George, every movement is significant, like the strut of cranes...

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: Cranes?  Who needs to walk like a crane?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: That's just my interpretation. Actually it's a dance designed as a sentiment of courtly manners. You see?  Walk in a gently 'Z'. There are four distinct movements...

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: What do you really think of the minuet, anyway?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: It's stupid, of course.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: Then why are you teaching me...?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Perhaps you best ask, why you wish it.  You asked William to teach you manners, philosophy, decorum... as I said, it's completely stupid.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: I always though London was the place to be:  capital of the world, the most spectacular city on earth.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: The place to want to be is America. Every English child dreams of it. I dreamt it.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: I think America suits you.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Do you?  When I saw those men yesterday in the field... and the women and children in those hovels? I'm not so sure if America is as far from England as I'd hoped.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: It's the freest land on earth.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Is it?  Well, I'm scared of what we've become in our freedom.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: Well, we must be who we must be...

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: And to think I am teaching you to become one of them...

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: What else should I become?  There's no difference between Virginia and England.  I must be educated if I'm to take my place in society.  My father couldn't afford to send me to England for school -- he made a shambles of our fortunes.  Everyone laughs at me.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: I don't laugh at you, George.  I like you.  I like you because you will never, ever make it as an aristocrat... and that's because you're completely incompetent at hiding your feelings.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: I think I will disappoint you.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Let's get you darker!

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: You're out of your mind!

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Why?  Juba was an African and you want to look the part -- hold still.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: They can use their imaginations.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Those people?  I doubt they'd think of this.  Ooo, you're wonderful this color!

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: I've been surprised in an unguarded hour, But must not now go back; the love that lay, Half smothered in my breast, has broke through all, Its weak restraints, and burns in its full lustre.  I cannot, if I would, conceal it from thee.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: I'm lost in ecstasy!  And dost thou love, Thou charming maid?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: And dost thou live to ask it?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Remember, George, "It is dangerous to be right in matters on which the established authorities are wrong."

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: That's good... who?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Voltaire, of course...

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: You are a slave owner!  You have been illegally surveying lands beyond the Ohio Valley!  That land belongs to the natives!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: That land belongs to the strongest.

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: All people have rights!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Just because they are born?

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Who says so?

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: I say!

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: I see...

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: And 'others', say... have you even read Locke, Vattel, Voltaire, Diderot...

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: Are these philosopher going to be here to help you fight your war? You know why I don't trust revolutions?  Because each of us is who we are:  we make speeches, print pamphlets, and we never change.  The world is not a philosophical abstraction, Mister Adams, it's us.  And, I don't believe you can ever change human nature.

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: You hear that?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: That?  I hear a mob:  unemployed, drunkards, vagabonds... the world's dregs.

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: Well, I hear 'The People'.  Indentured servants, freed slaves... escaped slaves.  The world's castaways.  And, my fear is, in the scramble for power that's coming, you will betray them.

turns.speaker: SAM ADAMS
turns.text: Is that your test of patriotism, George; if a man will die for you?

turns.speaker: WASHINGTON
turns.text: God damn you, Sam Adams!  You wanted a revolutionary army and now that we've really got one it scares you more than it does the British!

turns.speaker: WILLIAM
turns.text: The land here is best for grain and corn.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: Though, sometimes we get frost and that can cut the season.

turns.speaker: WILLIAM
turns.text: My daughter, I ask only...

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: This, this is life indeed!  Life worth preserving, Such life as Juba never felt till now.

turns.speaker: WILLIAM
turns.text: For God sake, get that horrid stuff off your face.  You look like a damned slave!  It's damned humiliating.

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: Juba was a Numidian.

turns.speaker: WILLIAM
turns.text: He was not black!  He was... tan! Weathered!

turns.speaker: YOUNG WASHINGTON
turns.text: William, we've been studying hard, I really know my stuff.

turns.speaker: WILLIAM
turns.text: Don't be silly, you have whole worlds to fathom.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: What is this?

turns.speaker: ATTENDANT
turns.text: An Oldsmobile Silhouette.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I reserved a Cadillac.

turns.speaker: ATTENDANT
turns.text: Yeah, well, this one's the Cadillac of minivans.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You're kidding me, right?

turns.speaker: ATTENDANT
turns.text: Hey, you want La Tierra Rent-A-Car just over there, but I think all they got are Rabbit convertibles.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Shit, now someone's gotta climb down there and get him.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: You didn't have to shoot him, Bo. We coulda just beat him up some.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: You see that? The way the man just went right over?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: Cat, that's the lamest idea I've ever heard.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Yeah, well, I'm bored, Bear. I wanna make movies.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: And I mean high up in it.  That's why Harry's gonna make Mr. Lovejoy with me, not Chili Palmer.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: Mr. Lovejoy? That's cute, Bo.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Doesn't matter what it's called, Harry's got Martin Weir and it's gonna be big.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: They all sound big at the talking stage.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: He knew it was a set up. He was ready for it.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: So where's the money?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: I guess still in the locker.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: You guess? You mean you don't know?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: I mean I don't care.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: You see the paper?

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: I seen it, but I don't believe it. Says Harry shot Ronnie five times. Four to the chest and one through his foot.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: His foot. Jeez, poor Ronnie...

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Yeah, I'm really gonna miss him.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Listen, tonight, later on, I got one for you doesn't involve any heavy work. I want you to go have a look around Chili Palmer's hotel room.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: I can't. I got to take Farrah to Satan's place down in Costa Mesa.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: Her mother. Not that it matters because I don't work for you no more. I quit. I just wanted to come by, tell you to your face so there's no misunderstanding.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Whoa... This is the man used to jump offa high buildings?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: Into air bags. There's no cushion under what you're doing. I'm out of it, Cat. I'm done.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Bear. The Colombians are in L.A. Seems they all upset about their money. That ain't enough, as a bonus, it turns out the yoyo was Escobar's nephew.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: That's your problem. You shouldn't've smoked the guy.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: He's gonna plea-deal his way out. Give up this ace stunt man now one of the West Coast dope kings, if they go easy on the Cat.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: Come here, Farrah...

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: I heard in the Federal joints they let you spend an extra five minutes at the glass with your Daddy on Father's Day.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: Farrah. Come here.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: After this one, I'm out, Cat, you understand? This is the last time we talk to each other.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Remember Harry's story about the dry cleaner Palmer was after? Guy who stole the three hundred grand from the airline?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: What about him?

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: I was thinking tonight you could go have a look around Palmer's hotel room while I go check out Karen Flores' place. See if he hasn't stashed it somewhere.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: And if we don't happen to find it under Palmer's mattress or inside Karen Flores' undie drawer? What then?

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Just do what I told you and meet me back here at midnight.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: You get the money?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: No. What's this?

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Plan B. Here ya go, honey...

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: Trade for what?

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: The money. Fuck. I gotta think...

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: You get life for kidnapping.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Calm down, Bear...

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: Calm down? We're going away for life and you tell me to calm down?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: Hell, why not just shoot her? Why not shoot everybody. Fuckin' shoot me. Shoot the fuckin' president?

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Don't fade on me now, Bear. Not unless you wanna hold Farrah on your lap in a room fulla felons.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: And that's for the airport.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Hey, he should have a weapon, a knife or something.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: We'll get it later.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: You keep hittin' him like that, he ain't gonna look like he broke in anymore, he gonna look like someone beat him up and then shot him.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: You're right.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I don't know how I could've missed you with that shirt on. It's the same as the other one you had only the hibiscus are a different color. Right?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: So you didn't have the key with you.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You think I'd be standing here? You set somebody up and you want it to work, it has to be a surprise. Can you remember that?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: You spotted them, huh?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: What, did you see it work in some movie you got beat up in?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: I have to ask you for that key.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: What, the setup didn't work so you want the key back?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: Catlett says if you don't open the locker the deal's off.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You serious? This is how you guys do business? I can't believe you aren't dead.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Look, there's no fuckin' way I'm gonna give you the key, outside of you point a gun at my head. Then we might have something to talk about. Now step away from the car.

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: I don't need a gun. Where is it? If it isn't on you, it's around here someplace.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: What're you hanging around with a guy like that for? You were in the movies, right? A stuntman? What's he ever done he can talk about? You feel okay?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: Not too bad.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: How 'bout when you went down the stairs?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: I think I pulled my quadriceps.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: So... how many movies you been in?

turns.speaker: BEAR
turns.text: About sixty.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: No shit? What're some of 'em?

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Where is my nephew?

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Your who?

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Yayo. Where is he?

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: He's my sister's kid. No papa. Not too bright. Personally, I think he's a retard. I only gave him the job as a favor for my sister, you understand?

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Sure. Family. I know how that goes.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: He comes up here with our product. He suppose to come home with five hundred thousand dollars. He never shows up. Meanwhile, my sister's going crazy calling me all the time worried about him. Me, I just wanna know what happened to my focking money.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Well, I don't know. I gave the man his money, sent him on his way.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: You gave him the money?

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: I gave him a key to a locker that had the money in it.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Now why would you do that? Put the money in a locker?

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Because there were a zillion DEA guys hanging around the terminal.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: A zillion, huh? That's a lot.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: Maybe your nephew panicked, took off.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Where's your partner, the jumpy one? Why isn't he here?

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: He's around someplace.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: I hear he's around Palm Springs. Dealing our product. Product we sold to you for five hundred thousand dollars.  Why do you keep talking to me bullshit? I think maybe I have Ramon and Ceasar staple your tongue to your chin. What do you think?

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: You know, you speak very good English, Mr. Escobar.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: I went to UC San Diego.  We're gonna spend the weekend at the Universal Sheraton. We're gonna take the tour. See the shark. Check out the Miami Vice Action Spectacular. After, we'll come here, get our money.

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: What's this movie you're doing first?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Harry, let me answer that.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: But first I want to know who I'm talking to. Am I talking to you, or am I talking to him?

turns.speaker: BO CATLETT
turns.text: You can talk to me.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: That's what I thought. So let me put it this way...
